name: Erdős #5: Prime Gap Limit Points
description: Is the set S of limit points of (p_{n+1} - p_n) / log(n) equal to [0, ∞]? Equivalently: for any C ≥ 0, does there exist a subsequence where the normalized gap converges to C?

insights: Westzynthius (1931): ∞ ∈ S - arbitrarily large prime gaps exist
Goldston-Pintz-Yildirim (2005): 0 ∈ S - small gaps exist infinitely often
Erdős-Ricci: S has positive Lebesgue measure
Hildebrand-Maier: S contains arbitrarily large finite values
Pintz: [0, c] ⊆ S for some small c > 0
Merikoski: at least 1/3 of [0, ∞) belongs to S, and S has bounded gaps
Zhang (2013): bounded gaps ≤ 70M exist, improved to ≤ 246 by Polymath
The conjecture asks if S = [0, ∞], i.e., every non-negative real is a limit point
Mathlib has Nat.nth Prime for the nth prime number
builtItems: nthPrime_zero, nthPrime_one, nthPrime_two proofs at Erdos5PrimeGaps.lean:112-121
mathlibGaps: No direct formalization of limit points of sequences in general
Prime Number Theorem not formally proven in Mathlib (needed for asymptotic gap analysis)
No Cramér's conjecture or related density results
nextSteps: Prove zhang_implies_zero_limit from bounded gaps axiom
